thread.title: Emerging Stocks Decline With Currencies Amid Global Growth Risks
thread.title_full: Emerging Stocks Decline With Currencies Amid Global Growth Risks - Bloomberg Business

author: Anuchit Nguyen
title: Emerging Stocks Decline With Currencies Amid Global Growth Risks
text:
Emerging-market stocks retreated from a one-month high as concerns about slowing global economic growth and higher U.S. interest rates damped demand for riskier assets. Malaysia’s ringgit halted a six-day gain.
Samsung Electronics Co. sank 2.9 percent in Seoul after Hyundai Securities Co. cut the stock’s price target. Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. led a 1.8 percent drop in the Taiex index. Hong Kong’s Hang Seng China Enterprises Index declined 1.6 percent amid concern government intervention will fail to shore up the the Chinese stock market amid signs of a deeper economic slowdown. The ringgit weakened 1.3 percent versus the dollar and South Korea’s won fell 1 percent.
The MSCI Emerging Markets Index tumbled 1.5 percent to 817.54 at 1:09 p.m. in Hong Kong, the most since Sept. 4. Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen highlighted China’s slowing economy and financial market turmoil when she left borrowing costs near zero last week. Three Fed policy makers over the weekend separately argued that an interest-rate increase is still warranted this year. A preliminary Chinese manufacturing report Wednesday will likely signal a contraction, according to estimates compiled by Bloomberg.
“The slow economic recovery in China will have a prolonged impact on other developing countries,” with investors expecting further weak data this week,” Thanomsak Saharatchai, the head of research at KT Zmico Securities Co., said by phone in Bangkok. “The concern about U.S. interest rate increase has now heightened after comments by some officials.”
Cheaper Equities MSCI’s developing-markets index has fallen 15 percent this year and trades at 10.8 times projected 12-month earnings, a 28 percent discount to the MSCI World Index, according to data compiled by Bloomberg.
All 10 industry groups in the emerging-stocks measure fell, led by technology shares. Samsung dropped the most since Aug. 21 after Hyundai Securities trimmed the stock’s price forecast to 1.5 million won ($1,277) from 1.65 million won. The Kospi index sank 1.5 percent and the won slid the most in two weeks. Taiwan Semiconductor lost 1.9 percent as the Taiex dropped 1.8 percent.
The Hang Seng China Enterprises gauge index headed for the steepest decline in more than two weeks. Concerns about the outlook for the world’s second-biggest economy deepened after five interest-rate cuts since November and plans to boost state spending have yet to revive growth amid overcapacity and producer-price deflation. The Shanghai Composite Index increased 1.3 percent in trading volumes that were 45 percent below the 30-day average.
The FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI Index lost 1.3 percent. The ringgit weakened after posting the biggest weekly gain in two years. The Malaysian currency is already Asia’s worst-performing currency in 2015 as falling crude prices weigh on the oil exporter’s earnings. Crude traded near $45 a barrel in New York.
